case_name: Zamindars of Hemgir and Sarpgarh v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 112 and 113 of 1960 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 11 2 and 11 3 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 25, 1957, of the Orissa High Court in 0. J. C. Nos. 164 and 181 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated April 25, 1957, of the Orissa High Court in O.J.C. Nos. 164 and 181 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 25, 1957, of the Orissa High Court in 0. J. C. Nos. 164 and 181 of 1954. C. Chatterjee, M. S. Mohanty, A. N. Singh and B. P. Maheshwari, for the appellants.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 16, 1962 by SINHA, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 16. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C.J.-These two appeals on certificates of fitness granted by the High Court of Orissa raise the question of the constitutionality

facts.text: Appeals challenge constitutionality of Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act (Orissa XVII of 1954) amending Orissa Estates Abolition Act (Orissa 1 of 1952).

anchor.surface_text: raise the question of the constitutionality of the Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act Orissa XVII of 1954 amending the main Act, the Orissa Estates Abolition Act Orissa 1 of 1952 , which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Zamindars of Hemgir and Sarpgarh filed writ petitions under Art. 226 in Orissa High Court against State of Orissa and Collector of Sundargarh.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the two Zamindars of Hemgir and Sarpgarh moved the High Court of Orissa under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of mandamus against the State of Orissa and the Collector of Sundargarh, which is a district formed after Merger.

facts.text: Sundargarh is a district formed after Merger, previously part of feudatory State of Gangpur.

anchor.surface_text: against the State of Orissa and the Collector of Sundargarh, which is a district formed after Merger. Previously it was part of the feudatory State of Gangpur. The two petitioners Zamindaries covered about 540 sq. miles between them.

facts.text: Zamindaries of petitioners covered about 540 sq. miles.

anchor.surface_text: Previously it was part of the feudatory State of Gangpur. The two petitioners Zamindaries covered about 540 sq. miles between them. The petitioners in the High Court in their petitions, claimed a sovereign status

facts.text: Petitioners claimed sovereign status citing historical literature including Imperial Gazetteer, Treaties, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The two petitioners Zamindaries covered about 540 sq. miles between them. The petitioners in the High Court in their petitions, claimed a sovereign status and referred to a mass of historical literature, including references to the Imperial Gazetteer by W. W. Hunter, Sir Richard Temples Treaties, Zamindaries, Chieftainships in Central Provinces, and other official records.

facts.text: Orissa High Court found remote ancestors of petitioners were Bhuiyan Chiefs, original settlers who became chieftains exercising sovereign powers.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found that the remote ancestors of the petitioners were Bhuiyan Chiefs, who were the original settlers and who had in course of time become the chieftains of the place, exercising sovereign powers.

facts.text: Bhuiyan Chiefs accepted suzerainty of Rajput Rulers of Gangpur and surrendered sovereign rights.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, when the Rajput Rulers of Gangpur settled in that area, these Bhuiyan Chiefs accepted the suzerainty of those Rulers and gradually surrendered their sovereign rights.

facts.text: Petitioners paid annual Takolis, originally as tributes, later indistinguishable from land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: They used to pay annual Takolis, which they originally paid as tributes to the suzerain, but which later became indistinguishable from land revenue.

facts.text: Status vis-a-vis Ruler of Gangpur undefined, but described as Zamindars in revenue settlements with Khewats issued.

anchor.surface_text: Their status vis-a-vis the Ruler of Gangpur remained undefined, though in successive revenue settlements made by the Ruler of Gangpur, with the concurrence of the then political Department, of the Government of India, they were described as Zamindars, and Khewats were issued to them.

facts.text: High Court concluded Zamindars lost all vestiges of sovereignty, became subject to laws of Ruler of Gangpur.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on an examination of the relevant evidence, came to the conclusion that these Zamindars ultimately lost all vestiges of their sovereignty, and as a result of historical process became subject to the laws promulgated by the Ruler of Gangpur,

facts.text: Ruler of Gangpur merged his State with State of Orissa effective January 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and that when the Ruler merged his State with the State of Orissa, with effect from January 1, 1948, these petitioners were no better than mere subjects and had absolutely no claims to sovereign power.

facts.text: Considerable forest areas formed part of petitioners' land, no separate existence in law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also found that considerable forest areas formed part of the land which belonged to them, and that these forest areas had no separate and distinct existence in the eye of law.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petitions, directed parties to bear own costs.

anchor.surface_text: In that view of the matter, these petitions were dismissed and both parties were directed to bear their own costs.

facts.text: High Court granted certificates of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, in each case, moved the High Court and obtained the necessary certificate for coming up in appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Orissa Act 1 of 1952 came into force in February 1952; Government notified petitioners' property under it.

anchor.surface_text: When the Orissa Act 1 of 1952, the main Act, was enacted and came into force in February 1952, the Government of Orissa notified the petitioners property also as coming within the purview of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioners challenged Orissa Act 1 of 1952 in High Court under Art. 226; majority held Act valid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants along with another person claiming the same rights, belonging to Nagra, moved the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the constitutionality of the Act. Those applications were heard by the High Court, and by majority it was held that the Act was valid

facts.text: Supreme Court in Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa allowed appeals of Hemgir and Sarpgarh proprietors as not intermediaries under s.2(h).

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of this Court is reported as Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa 1 This Court allowed the appeal of the proprietors of Hemgir and Sarpgarh on the ground that they were no Intermediaries as defined in s. 2 h of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court distinguished Nagra Zamindari as intermediary due to acknowledgment of overlordship of Raja of Gangpur.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the proprietor of Nagra Zamindari, by a majority judgment, it was decided that he came within the definition of an intermediary, and that, therefore, his land would come within the definition of an estate, as defined in s. 2 g of the Act.

facts.text: Orissa Legislature passed Amending Act XVII of 1954 recasting definitions of 'estate' and 'intermediary'.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the decision of this Court, allowing the appeals of the Zamindars of Hemgir and Sarpgarh and prohibiting the State of Orissa from taking over possession of those two zamindaries under the Act, the Orissa Legislature passed the Amending Act XVII of 1854

facts.text: Amended definitions include wide terms to bring petitioners' lands within the Act per statement of objects.

anchor.surface_text: In the statement of objects and reasons for amending the Act, it was indicated that these wide definitions of those two terms were enacted so that the decision of this Court with particular reference to these two properties may no stand in the way of acquiring them.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellants not sovereign holders but intermediaries holding interest between raiyat and state.

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to accede to the argument that the all inclusive definition of intermediary, as given in the amended cl. 11 of s. 2 would no cover the interest of the appellants. If it is held, as we must hold in agreement with the High Court,

facts.text: Takoli payments were land revenue, not tribute.

anchor.surface_text: The main argument, therefore, of Mr. Chatterjee was directed to showing that the appellants held the lands as sovereign power, and that the Takoli which they paid to the Raja of Gangpur was only in the nature of tribute and no land revenue.

facts.text: No vestige of sovereignty left with appellants at merger of Gangpur State.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, at the date of the merger of the Gangpur State in the State of Orissa, no even a vestige of sovereignty was left with these appellants.

facts.text: Laws of Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarpgarh by their own force.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the High Court that the various laws which were in force in Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarapgarh also, by their own force and no as a result of any agreement between sovereign States.

facts.text: Administrative control passed to Ruler of Gangpur.

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore the various departments of administration were also in the hands of the staff maintained and supervised by the Ruler of Gangpur.

facts.text: By 1947, appellants had no sovereign authority left.

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned with the year 1947, and in that there is no evidence on behalf of the appellants that they had any sovereign authority left in them.

facts.text: Petitioners' lands liable to acquisition under the Act as estates of intermediaries.

anchor.surface_text: There is, thus, no escape from the conclusion that their interest in their lands was liable to be acquired under the Act.

facts.text: Appeals held without merit.

anchor.surface_text: No other point was urged before us in support of the appeals, and as the only point urged in this Court has no substance in it, the appeals must be held to be without any merit.

anchor.surface_text: The main argument, therefore, of Mr. Chatterjee was directed to showing that the appellants held the lands as sovereign power, and that the Takoli which they paid to the Raja of Gangpur was only in the nature of tribute and no land revenue. In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention. It is true that there is no evidence of an act of State in the nature of a conquest by the Raja of Gangpur or that the Raja imposed his sovereignty on these principalities by force of arms or by express agreement.

issues.text: the question of the constitutionality of the Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act Orissa XVII of 1954 amending the main Act, the Orissa Estates Abolition Act Orissa 1 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: raise the question of the constitutionality of the Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act Orissa XVII of 1954 amending the main Act, the Orissa Estates Abolition Act Orissa 1 of 1952 , which hereinafter will be referred to as the Act.

issues.text: whether their lands were estates as defined in Art. 31A (ii)(a) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the petitioners contention that their lands were not estates as defined in Art. 31A (ii)(a) of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the Act, in so far as it applies to the petitioners, was discriminatory contravening Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also rejected the contention that the Act, in so far as it applies to the petitioners, was discriminatory. The High Court thus held that Art. 14 of the Constitution had not been contravened.

issues.text: whether the Act was void under Art. 254(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the Act was not void under Art. 254(1) of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the violation of Art. 17(2) of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was justiciable

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the so called violation of Art. 17(2) of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights promulgated by the General Assembly of the United Nations on December 10, 1948, to which India was a party, was not justiciable.

issues.text: whether even after the amendment of the Act the legislature has achieved its objective of bringing the land of these two petitioners within the mischief of the Act

anchor.surface_text: namely, that even after the amendment of the Act the legislature has failed to achieve its objective of bringing the land of these two petitioners within the mischief of the Act. In other words, the contention is that the appellants were sovereign rulers whose States could not be taken over by the State of Orissa even after the amendment of the Act, as aforesaid.

issues.text: whether the interest of the appellants would come within the purview of the definition of intermediary in the amended s. 2(h)

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, necessary to find whether the interest of the appellants, in order to be liable to acquisition under the Act, would come within the purview of the definition of intermediary.

issues.text: whether the appellants held the lands as sovereign power and the Takoli paid was only in the nature of tribute and no land revenue

anchor.surface_text: The main argument, therefore, of Mr. Chatterjee was directed to showing that the appellants held the lands as sovereign power, and that the Takoli which they paid to the Raja of Gangpur was only in the nature of tribute and no land revenue. In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention.

issues.text: whether there is scope for applying the doctrine of act of State to these principalities

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there is no evidence of an act of State in the nature of a conquest by the Raja of Gangpur or that the Raja imposed his sovereignty on these principalities by force of arms or by express agreement.

issues.text: whether the appellants were intermediaries as defined in s. 2(h) of the Act and their lands estates under s. 2(g)

anchor.surface_text: This Court allowed the appeal of the proprietors of Hemgir and Sarpgarh on the ground that they were no Intermediaries as defined in s. 2 h of the Act. As regards the proprietor of Nagra Zamindari, by a majority judgment, it was decided that he came within the definition of an intermediary, and that, therefore, his land would come within the definition of an estate, as defined in s. 2 g of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Act of State can result from historical process without conquest or treaty

arguments.claim: Zamindars lost sovereignty and became subject to Ruler of Gangpur's laws via historical process

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on an examination of the relevant evidence, came to the conclusion that these Zamindars ultimately lost all vestiges of their sovereignty, and as a result of historical process became subject to the laws promulgated by the Ruler of Gangpur,

arguments.claim: Appellants are intermediaries under amended s.2(h) as holders of interest between raiyat and state

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to accede to the argument that the all inclusive definition of intermediary, as given in the amended cl. 11 of s. 2 would not cover the interest of the appellants. If it is held, as we must hold in agreement with the High Court,

arguments.claim: Takoli payments are land revenue under Explanation I to s.2(g)

anchor.surface_text: and the Takoli paid by them to the Ruler of Gangpur and later to the State of Orissa was land revenue within Explanation I read with Explanation III to s. 2 g which defines estate.

arguments.claim: Doctrine of act of State applies via historical process as per Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by this Court in Promod Chandra Deb v. Stateof Orissa 1 that an act of State may be the taking over of sovereign powers either by conquest or by treaty or by cession or otherwise. It may have happened on a particular date by a public declaration or proclamation, or it may have been the result of a historical process spread over many years,

arguments.claim: Position analogous to Bhomicharas of Rajasthan and Cis-Sutlej jagirs

anchor.surface_text: Their position is analogous to that of the Bhomicharas of Rajasthan, dealt with by this Court in Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan 1 and that of the Cis- Sutlej jagir in Punjab, dealt with by this Court in Amarsarjit Singh v. State of Punjab 2 .

arguments.claim: Laws of Gangpur in force in Hemgir and Sarpgarh by own force, administrative control with Ruler

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the High Court that the various laws which were in force in Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarapgarh also, by their own force and not as a result of any agreement between sovereign States. Furthermore the various departments of administration were also in the hands of the staff maintained and supervised by the Ruler of Gangpur.

arguments.court_reasoning: No vestige of sovereignty left at merger

holdings.text: The appellants were not holders of sovereign States but held an interest in land between the raiyat and the State, making them intermediaries under the amended definition in s. 2(h).

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to accede to the argument that the all inclusive definition of intermediary, as given in the amended cl. 11 of s. 2 would no cover the interest of the appellants. If it is held, as we must hold in agreement with the High Court,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with High Court findings on historical loss of sovereignty; all-inclusive definition covers any holders between raiyat and state.

holdings.text: The Takoli payments made by the appellants to the Raja of Gangpur were in the nature of land revenue, not tribute.

anchor.surface_text: The main argument, therefore, of Mr. Chatterjee was directed to showing that the appellants held the lands as sovereign power, and that the Takoli which they paid to the Raja of Gangpur was only in the nature of tribute and no land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's contention; falls within Explanation I to s. 2(g) as payments claimable by State from intermediary.

holdings.text: No vestige of sovereignty was left with the appellants at the date of the merger of Gangpur State in Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, at the date of the merger of the Gangpur State in the State of Orissa, no even a vestige of sovereignty was left with these appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings on laws and administration of Gangpur applying by own force; no evidence of sovereign authority in 1947.

holdings.text: The doctrine of act of State applies through historical process, vesting sovereignty in Ruler of Gangpur without conquest or treaty.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the High Court that the various laws which were in force in Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarapgarh also, by their own force and no as a result of any agreement between sovereign States.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa; sovereignty acquired by historical process over years.

holdings.text: The interest in lands of the petitioners was liable to be acquired under the Orissa Estates Abolition Act as amended.

anchor.surface_text: There is, thus, no escape from the conclusion that their interest in their lands was liable to be acquired under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: As intermediaries under s.2(h) and estates under s.2(g); amended definitions cover them post-Biswambhar Singh.

holdings.text: The appeals are without merit and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: No other point was urged before us in support of the appeals, and as the only point urged in this Court has no substance in it, the appeals must be held to be without any merit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's sole contention on sovereignty rejected; upholds High Court on all issues including constitutionality.

holdings.text: The appellants had no sovereign authority left in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned with the year 1947, and in that there is no evidence on behalf of the appellants that they had any sovereign authority left in them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence presented; historical process completed by then, analogous to Bhomicharas and Cis-Sutlej jagirs.

holdings.text: Laws of Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarpgarh by their own force, and administrative control was with Ruler of Gangpur.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the High Court that the various laws which were in force in Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarapgarh also, by their own force and number as a result of any agreement between sovereign States. Furthermore the various departments of administration were also in the hands of the staff maintained and supervised by the Ruler of Gangpur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings accepted; indicates loss of sovereignty.

precedents.citation: Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa 1  This Court allowed the appeal of the proprietors of Hemgir and Sarpgarh on the ground that they were number Intermediaries as defined in s. 2 h  of the Act. As regards the proprietor of Nagra Zamindari, by a majority judgment, it was decided that he came within the definition of an intermediary, and that, therefore, his land would companye within the definition of an estate, as defined in s. 2 g  of the Act. This Court distinguished the case of Nagra from that of the other two on the ground that the Zamindar of Nagra had acknowledged the overlordship of the Raja of Gangpur.

precedents.case_name: Biswambhar Singh v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: Hemgir and Sarpgarh proprietors were not Intermediaries as defined in s. 2(h) of the Act; Nagra proprietor was an intermediary having acknowledged overlordship of Raja of Gangpur
precedents.cited_holding: Appeal allowed for Hemgir and Sarpgarh; Nagra case decided against proprietor by majority

precedents.citation: Promod Chandra Deb v. Stateof Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Promod Chandra Deb v. Stateof Orissa 1  that an act of State may be the taking over of sovereign powers either by companyquest or by treaty or by cession or otherwise. It may have happened on a particular date by a public declaration or proclamation, or it may have been the result of a historical process spread over many years, and sovereign powers including the right to legislate in that territory and to administer it may be acquired without the territory itself merging in the new State.

precedents.case_name: Promod Chandra Deb v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: an act of State may be the taking over of sovereign powers either by conquest or by treaty or by cession or otherwise; it may be result of historical process spread over many years; sovereign powers may be acquired without territory merging

precedents.citation: Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan  1

anchor.surface_text: Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan  1  and that of the Cis- Sutlej jagir in Punjab, dealt with by this Court in Amarsarjit Singh v. State of Punjab  2 . Hence, even though there is numberevidence of actual companyquest of the territory of the appellants by the Raja of Gangpur, number of active imposition of the sovereignty of that Raja over the territories in question, the fact remains that as a result of a companytinuous process, the erstwhile rulers of these territories submitted to the sovereignty of the Raja with the result that the Ruler of Gangpur became, in effect, the sovereign power exercising his sovereign authority over those territories also,

precedents.case_name: Thakur Amar Singhji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: position analogous to that of the Bhomicharas of Rajasthan

precedents.citation: Amarsarjit Singh v. State of Punjab  2

anchor.surface_text: Amarsarjit Singh v. State of Punjab  2 . Hence, even though there is numberevidence of actual companyquest of the territory of the appellants by the Raja of Gangpur, number of active imposition of the sovereignty of that Raja over the territories in question, the fact remains that as a result of a companytinuous process, the erstwhile rulers of these territories submitted to the sovereignty of the Raja with the result that the Ruler of Gangpur became, in effect, the sovereign power exercising his sovereign authority over those territories also, and the outward symbols of sovereignty were that the laws of Gangpur State were in force in Hemgir and Sarpgarh areas also number by virtue of any orders of the appellants but by their own force, as has been pointed out by the High Court on a companysideration of all the relevant evidence, which need number be recapitulated here.

precedents.case_name: Amarsarjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: position analogous to that of the Cis-Sutlej jagir in Punjab
